facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 48 and 80 of 1960 filed by special leave from Bombay High Court judgments dated December 11, 1959 and March 2, 1960 in Criminal Revision Application No. 100 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTIONCriminal Appeals Nos. 48 and 80 of 1960. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated December 11, 1959 and March 2, 1960 of the Bombay High Court Rajkot  Now Gujarat High Court  In criminal Revision Application No. 100 of 1959.

facts.text: Three appellants along with Keshavlal Nagjibhai prosecuted under s. 167(81) of the Sea Customs Act before magistrate at Porbander.

anchor.surface_text: The three appellants along with one more person, namely, Keshavlal Nagjibhai were prosecuted under s. 167  81  of the Sea Customs Act, No. 8 of 1878,  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Vallabhdas Liladhar purchased smuggled gold weighing a little more than 84 tolas from an Arab on December 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case briefly was that Vallabhdas Liladhar, who is number dead, came in companytact with an Arab from whom he purchased smuggled gold weighing a little more than 84 tolas on December 1, 1956.

facts.text: Vallabhdas Liladhar borrowed Rs. 3,600 from the other two appellants and Keshavlal about November 28, 1956 to make the purchase.

anchor.surface_text: Before this, Vallabhdas Liladhar had borrowed Rs. 3,600/- from the other two appellants and Keshavlal about November 28, 1956, in order to make the purchase.

facts.text: Vallabhdas Liladhar informed the other two appellants and Keshavlal of the purchase and wanted their help in disposal of the gold.

anchor.surface_text: After making the purchase, Vallabhdas Liladhar came to Porbunder to the house of the other two appellants and Keshavlal and informed them of the purchase and wanted their help in the disposal of the gold.

facts.text: Narandas Nagjibhai and Vallabhdas Nagjibhai are brothers, Keshavlal is also their brother.

anchor.surface_text: The other two appellants namely, Narandas Nagjibhai and Vallabhdas Nagjibhai are brothers. Keshavlal was also the brother of these two appellants.

facts.text: Narandas Nagjibhai asked Vallabhdas Nagjibhai to take the gold to Bantwa and sell at Rs. 103 per tola or contact at Bantwa bus stand.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case further was that Narandas Nagjibhai asked Vallabhdas Nagjibhai to take the gold to Bantwa and sell it at the rate of Rs. 103/- or so per tola. Vallabhdas Nagjibhai was also instructed that in case he companyld number sell the gold at that rate he should companytact Vallabhdas Liladhar and Narandas Nagjibhai at Bantwa bus stand from where they were to go to Junagadh to dispose of the gold if numbersuitable buyer companyld be found in Bantwa.

facts.text: Vallabhdas Nagjibhai proceeded to Bantwa by bus on December 2, 1956 in the afternoon.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently Vallabhdas Nagjibhai proceeded to Bantwa by bus on December 2, 1956 in the afternoon.

facts.text: Inspector Mehta received information about smuggling and intercepted Vallabhdas Nagjibhai at Kutiyana bus stand at about 3 p.m. on December 2, 1956 with Deputy Superintendent of Customs.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime information was received by Mehta who was Inspector of Customs about the smuggling of this gold. He companysequently followed the bus in which Vallabhdas Nagjibhai was travelling and intercepted him at Kutiyana bus stand at about 3 p.m. The Deputy Superintendent of Customs was also with Inspector Mehta and Vallabhdas Nagjibhai was taken down from the bus at Kutiyana.

facts.text: Five bars of gold weighing about 84 tolas bearing marks of foreign origin recovered from Vallabhdas Nagjibhai's possession.

anchor.surface_text: On search in the presence of witnesses, five bars of gold weighing about 84 tolas were recovered from his possession. All these five bars bore marks of foreign origin and were taken in possession by the customs authorities after preparing a recovery list.

facts.text: Collector of Central Excise Baroda confiscated the gold bars under s. 167(8) of the Act read with s. 23 of FERA 1947 and imposed penalties on October 7, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Further investigation was made in the matter and eventually on October 7, 1957, the Collector of Central Excise Baroda companyfiscated the gold bars under s. 167  8  of the Act read with s. 23 of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947 and also imposed a penalty of Rs. 1,000/- each on the three appellants and a penalty of Rs. 500/- on Keshavlal.

facts.text: Assistant Collector of Customs filed complaint under s. 167(81) before magistrate at Porbander on June 27, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter a companyplaint was filed by the Assistant Collector of Customs under s. 167 81  of the Act before the magistrate at Porbunder on June 27. 1958.

facts.text: Vallabhdas Liladhar claimed he brought the gold from Karachi in 1946, not purchased from Arab.

anchor.surface_text: The case of Vallabhdas Liladhar was that he had number purchased the gold from any Arab but had brought it with him from Karachi in the year 1946.

facts.text: Vallabhdas Nagjibhai admitted recovery of gold but claimed it belonged to Vallabhdas Liladhar and he did not know it was smuggled.

anchor.surface_text: Vallabhdas Nagjibhai admitted the recovery of gold from him but said that it belonged to Vallabhdas Liladhar and he was carrying it at the request of the latter and that he did number know that it was smuggled gold.

facts.text: Narandas Nagjibhai admitted Vallabhdas Liladhar came with gold but claimed it was not smuggled and belonged to him for sale.

anchor.surface_text: Narandas Nagjibhai also, admitted that Vallabhdas Liladhar had companye to their house with the gold but added that it was number smuggled gold and that Vallabhdas Liladhar had told him that it belonged to him and was for sale.

facts.text: Keshavlal claimed no knowledge or connection with the matter.

anchor.surface_text: Keshavlal, the fourth person, who has been acquitted, said that he did number know anything about the matter and had numberconnection with it.

facts.text: Appellants made statements before customs authorities admitting prosecution case that gold was smuggled and they were trying to dispose of it.

anchor.surface_text: It may be added that the three appellants had made statements before the customs authorities and those statements were also put in evidence in support of the prosecution case. In those statements, they practically admitted the prosecution case that the gold was smuggled gold and they were trying to dispose it of.

facts.text: Magistrate convicted all four under s.167(81), sentenced to RI six months and fine Rs.500 each.

anchor.surface_text: The magistrate companyvicted all the four persons under s. 167  81  of the Act and sentenced them to rigorous imprisonment for six months and a fine of Rs. 500/-

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge Porbander acquitted Keshavlal, dismissed appeals of three appellants upholding convictions and sentences.

anchor.surface_text: All the four companyvicted persons appealed to the Sessions Judge. The appeal was heard by the Additional Sessions Judge, Porbunder who acquitted Keshavlal. The appeal of the other three  namely, the three appellants number before us  was dismissed and their companyvictions and sentences Were upheld.

facts.text: High Court rejected revisions of Vallabhdas Liladhar and Vallabhdas Nagjibhai summarily, admitted and dismissed Narandas Nagjibhai's revision.

anchor.surface_text: The three appellants then went in revision to the High Court. The High Court rejected the revisions of Vallabhdas Liladhar and Vallabhdas Nagjibhai summarily. The revision application of Narandas Nagjibhai was admitted but was eventually dismissed.

facts.text: Vallabhdas Liladhar died, his appeal in Cr A 48 of 1960 abates.

anchor.surface_text: Vallabhdas Liladhar, one of the appellants in Cr. A 48 of 1960, is dead. So far therefore as he is companycerned, his appeal abates.

facts.text: Price of gold at relevant time over Rs. 105 per tola, appellants intending to sell at about Rs. 103 per tola.

anchor.surface_text: Though the price of gold at the relevant time was over Rs. 105/- per tola, the appellant were intending to sell these gold bars at a lower price of about Rs. 103/- per tola.

facts.text: Two appellants working as goldsmiths at Porbander.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants were working as goldsmiths at Porbunder and there was numberreason why the gold had to be sent elsewhere for disposal.

facts.text: Two appellants displayed undue haste in disposal of gold.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants displayed undue haste in the disposal of gold.

facts.text: Surreptitious manner in which gold bars kept by Vallabhdas Nagjibhai at recovery shows knowledge of smuggled gold.

anchor.surface_text: The surreptitious manner in which the gold bars were kept by Vallabhdas Nagjibhai as shown at the time of recovery shows that the appellants knew that they were dealing with smuggled gold.

issues.text: Whether the statements made to the customs authorities were inadmissible in evidence as they were not properly proved?

anchor.surface_text: The statements made to the customs authorities were inadmissible in evidence as they were not properly proved.

issues.text: Whether the statements made before the Collector of Customs were inadmissible in evidence under ss. 24 and 25 of the Indian Evidence Act?

anchor.surface_text: The statement made before the Collector of Customs were inadmissible in evidence under ss. 24 and 25 of the Indian Evidence Act.

issues.text: Whether, as the gold had already been confiscated and penalty had been imposed under s. 167 8 of the Act, there could be no further trial in a criminal court in view of s. 186 of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: As the gold had already been confiscated and penalty had been imposed under s. 167 8  of the Act, there could be nofurther trial in a criminal court in view of s. 186 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the ingredients of s. 167 81 are not satisfied in this case?

anchor.surface_text: The ingredients of s. 167 81  are not satisfied in this case.

issues.text: Whether the appeal of Vallabhdas Liladhar abates due to his death?

anchor.surface_text: Vallabhdas Liladhar, one of the appellants in Cr. A 48 of 1960, is dead. So far therefore as he is concerned, his appeal abates.

arguments.claim: The substantive sentence of imprisonment in the case of the two appellants before us may be reduced to the period already undergone.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it is urged that the substantive sentence of imprisonment in the case of the two appellants before us may be reduced to the period already undergone,

arguments.court_reasoning: No reason to interfere with the sentence in cases of this nature.

arguments.claim: Customs officers are not police officers and statements made to them are not inadmissible under s.25 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: As to the second point, we are of opinion that s. 25 of the Indian Evidence Act has no application on the facts of the present case which are on all fours with the facts in The State of Punjab v. Barkat Ram. In similar circumstances it was held by this Court in that case that customs officers are not police officers.

arguments.claim: s.186 does not bar prosecution under the Act after confiscation and penalty; it is an enabling provision.

anchor.surface_text: Next the appellants rely on s. 186 of the Act... Section 186 was thus meant for permitting prosecutions in addition to action under the Act... We cannot therefore read in s. 186 a bar by implication to a prosecution under the Act simply because s. 186 enables prosecution under any other law.

arguments.claim: All courts relied on statements and presumption under s.178A for conviction, but even without presumption evidence sufficient.

anchor.surface_text: In addition to the above circumstances, all the courts relied on the statements made by the two appellants before the customs authorities and the presumption under s. 178-A of the Act was raised and on that basis convicted the appellants, though the High Court held that even without the presumption under s. 178-A the evidence was sufficient.

holdings.text: Vallabhdas Liladhar's appeal abates due to his death.

anchor.surface_text: Vallabhdas Liladhar, one of the appellants in Cr. A 48 of 1960, is dead. So far therefore as he is concerned, his appeal abates.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural rule applies upon death of appellant in criminal appeal.

holdings.text: Statements made to customs authorities are admissible as properly proved by appellants' admission of signatures.

anchor.surface_text: Re. 1 . So far as the first point is concerned, the only argument is that the lawyer who signed the statements made before the customs authorities was not produced to prove them, and therefore the statements cannot be held to have been properly proved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants signed statements and admitted signatures; courts below disbelieved denial of knowledge; no need to examine lawyer.

holdings.text: Statements to customs officers inadmissible neither under s.25 nor s.24 of Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: As to the second point, we are of opinion that s. 25 of the Indian Evidence Act has no application on the facts of the present case which are on all fours with the facts in The State of Punjab v. Barkat Ram 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Customs officers not police officers per precedent (State of Punjab v. Barkat Ram); no inducement, threat or promise under s.24 as found by all courts.

holdings.text: s.186 of Sea Customs Act does not bar criminal prosecution under s.167(81) after confiscation and penalty under s.167(8).

anchor.surface_text: Next the appellants rely on s. 186 of the Act. which reads as follows -- The award of any confiscation, penalty or increased rate of duty under this Act by an officer of Customs shall not prevent the infliction of any punishment

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.186 is enabling provision to permit other punishments, not barring; historical context post cl.81 amendment; distinguishes Leo Roy Frey; ex abundanti cautela.

holdings.text: Ingredients of s.167(81) satisfied; dealing with known smuggled gold implies intent to defraud duty or evade prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: Next it is contended that the ingredients of cl. 81 of s. 167 are not satisfied inasmuch as it is not proved that the intention of the appellants was to defraud the government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proof of smuggled gold and knowing dealing entails intent to evade duty/prohibition as matter of course; concurrent findings on knowledge via circumstances upheld.

holdings.text: Concurrent findings of fact on knowledge of smuggling upheld; convictions under s.167(81) proper even without s.178A presumption.

anchor.surface_text: Before however we consider the points raised before us on behalf of the appellants we may refer to the circumstances which have been found established by all the courts and on the basis of which the conviction of the appellants has been upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstances (low price, haste, surreptitious possession, foreign marks, goldsmith knowledge) plus statements prove knowledge; counsel not challenging; High Court: sufficient sans presumption.

holdings.text: No interference with substantive sentence of imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it is urged that the substantive sentence of imprisonment in the case of the two appellants before us may be reduced to the period already undergone,

holdings.reasoning_summary: No reason to interfere in cases of this nature despite time on bail.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it is urged that the substantive sentence of imprisonment in the case of the two appellants before us may be reduced to the period already undergone, particularly, as the appellants, have been on bail since March 1960 and it would number be in the interest of justice to send them back to jail for a short period after four years when about half the sentence has already been served out. We however see numberreason to interfere with the sentence in cases of this nature.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal of Vallabhdas Liladhar abates due to his death; convictions and sentences of Vallabhdas Nagjibhai and Narandas Nagjibhai upheld with no interference or reduction
